title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement gerard.1787@gmail.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Introduction to segtest
text: can obtain offspring genotype frequencies via offspring_gf_2() offspring_gf_3(). two different parameterizations model meiosis. offspring_gf_3(), insert following parameters: tau: Probability quadrivalent formation. beta: Probability double reduction given quadrivalent formation gamma1: Probability AA_aa pairing parent 1 given bivalent formation. applicable p1 = 2. gamma2: Probability AA_aa pairing parent 2 given bivalent formation. applicable p2 = 2. p1: first parent’s genotype. p2: second parent’s genotype. Let’s generate example genotype frequencies. can play around parameter values .  offspring_gf_3() function safer use dependence preferential pairing parameter double reduction rate bounds values offspring_gf_2(), two-parameter model might accidentally choose values impossible. set checks values bounds depend maximum rate double reduction, can vary significantly. Please see Gerard et al. (2025) details.
code: gf <- offspring_gf_3(   tau = 1,    beta = 1/6,    gamma1 = 1/3,   gamma2 = 1/3,    p1 = 1,   p2 = 2) plot(   x = 0:4,   y = gf,   type = "h",   xlab = "Genotype",    ylab = "Frequency",   ylim = c(0, 1))

title: Introduction to segtest
text: ’ll first simulate data null segregation distortion true. LRT large pp-value, appropriate since segregation distortion.
code: set.seed(1) g1 <- 1 g2 <- 2 alpha <- 1/6 xi1 <- 1/3 xi2 <- 1/3 n <- 20 rd <- 10 x <- simf1g(   n = n,    g1 = g1,    g2 = g2,    alpha = alpha,    xi1 = xi1,    xi2 = xi2) gl <- simf1gl(   n = n,    rd = rd,    g1 = g1,   g2 = g2,    alpha = alpha,    xi1 = xi1,   xi2 = xi2) lout <- lrt_men_g4(x = x, g1 = g1, g2 = g2) lout$p_value #> [1] 0.5698342 lout_gl <- lrt_men_gl4(gl = gl, g1 = g1, g2 = g2) lout_gl$p_value #> [1] 0.6369666

title: Introduction to segtest
text: simulate data alternative true, get small pp-value.
code: x <- c(stats::rmultinom(n = 1, size = 20, prob = rep(1/5, 5))) lout <- lrt_men_g4(x = x, g1 = g1, g2 = g2) lout$p_value #> [1] 3.5306e-07

title: Introduction to segtest Version 2.0
text: can test segregation distortion using seg_lrt(). E.g., let’s test using data (known genotypes genotype likelihoods) simulated previous section: recommendation always use genotype log-likelihoods. seg_lrt() allows known genotypes, situation works best . default (model = "seg") assume organism segmental allopolyploid, account possible double reduction simplex loci. absolutely use models information organism: "seg": General segmental allopolyploid possible double reduction simplex loci. "allo_pp": Segmental allopolyploid complete bivalent pairing (double reduction). "allo": Pure allopolyploid (disomic inheritance). "auto": Pure autopolyploid complete bivalent pairing (double reduction). "auto_dr": Pure autopolyploid possible multivalent pairing (double reduction). "auto_allo": null hypothesis polymapR. allow non-valid genotypes via ob argument. upper bound proportion outliers. default, set 0.03. can set 0 (set outlier = FALSE) want outliers indicate segregation distortion. Make sure log-likelihoods base ee. base 10, ’ll get wrong pp-value: Don’t mess technical arguments (ntry, opt, optg, df_tol). optimization approximate degrees freedom test. Except possibly ntry. increase seeing weird results. let know, haven’t seen bad behavior ntry = 3 (default).
code: ## With known genotypes sout1 <- seg_lrt(x = x, p1_ploidy = 6, p2_ploidy = 6, p1 = 2, p2 = 4) sout1$p_value #> [1] 0.5820762 ## With genotype likelihoods sout2 <- seg_lrt(x = gl, p1_ploidy = 6, p2_ploidy = 6, p1 = 2, p2 = 4) sout2$p_value #> [1] 0.5860578 gl10 <- gl / log(10) seg_lrt(x = gl10, p1_ploidy = 6, p2_ploidy = 6, p1 = 2, p2 = 4)$p_value #> [1] 0.9141411

title: Parallel Testing
text: provide walk-run tests segregation distortion many loci parallel. Details methods may found Gerard et al. (2025a) Gerard et al. (2025b).

title: Parallel Testing
text: Data sets ufit, ufit2, ufit3 contain genotyping output updog::multidog() using three different models. ufit: Uses norm model without specifying parents . ufit2: Uses f1pp model, specifying parents. ufit3: Uses f1 model, specifying parents. can convert genotyping output seg_multi() expects using multidog_to_g(). use f1pp f1 models, use ether all_gl (run tests using genotype log-likelihoods) all_g (run tests assuming genotypes known) options, must specify ID’s parents. use f1pp f1 models, use either off_gl (run tests using genotype log-likelihoods) off_g (run tests assuming genotypes known) options. recommend always using genotype log-likelihoods. option known genotypes. Parallelization support provided future package. specify implement parallelization using future::plan(). run seg_multi(). shut parallelization future::plan(). common plan future::multisession(), specify number parallel processes workers argument. can get maximum number workers via future::availableCores() typically workload looks something like : output data frame. important parts snp p_value columns. looks like SNP 12_31029646 possible segregation distortion. Let’s compare expected frequencies (q0 column) observed modes. SNP 12_31029646 likely got flagged many individuals genotype 2, enough genotype 0. run outlier = FALSE, SNP 2_20070837 also flagged possible segregation distortion Let’s look posterior mode genotypes SNP 2_20070837: SNP 2_20070837 likely got flagged two individuals likely genotype 3, impossible parents genotypes 0 2. Including outlier = TRUE previously made ignore discrepancy (point). can get posterior probability individual outlier set ret_out = TRUE (previously ).

title: Parallel Testing
text: older function multi_lrt(), provides support tetraploids. can still use instead seg_multi() tetraploids. ’s little faster, account outliers, mostly setting outlier = FALSE.  one discrepancy caused new way calculate degrees freedom: two approaches give almost equivalent results time, new way little better.
code: future::plan(future::multisession(workers = 2)) mout3 <- multi_lrt(   g = o2$g,   p1 = o2$p1,    p2 = o2$p2 ) future::plan(future::sequential()) plot(   mout2$p_value,   mout3$p_value,   xlab = "seg_multi(outlier = FALSE)",    ylab = "multi_lrt()") abline(0, 1, lty = 2, col = 2) i <- which.max(abs(mout2$p_value - mout3$p_value)) mout2$df[[i]] #> [1] 2 mout3$df[[i]] #> [1] 3

what: Tests for Segregation Distortion in Polyploids
title: Tests for Segregation Distortion in Polyploids
text: Provides suite tests segregation distortion F1 populations polyploids various models meiosis. can use tests autopolyploids exhibit full polysomic inheritance, allopolyploids exhibit full disomic inheritance, segmental allopolyploids exhibit partial preferential pairing. Double reduction (optionally) fully accounted tetraploids, (optionally) partially accounted (simplex loci) higher ploidies. maximum proportion outliers can specified, methods can accommodate moderate levels double reduction non-simplex loci. Offspring genotypes can either known, genotype uncertainty can represented genotype likelihoods. Parent data may may provided, option. Parents can different (even) ploidies, option. package contains likelihood ratio chi-squared tests. See menbayes package Bayesian tests tetraploids. main functions : seg_multi(): Run likelihood ratio test segregation distortion parallel many loci. multidog_to_g: Format genotyping output updog::multidog() compatible input seg_multi(). seg_lrt(): Test segregation distortion even ploidy. gamfreq(): Gamete frequencies. gf_freq(): Genotype frequencies F1 population polyploids. drbounds(): Upper bounds double reduction rate(s) based two different extreme models meiosis. simgl(): Simulate genotype log-likelihoods given vector genotype counts. Older functions applicable tetraploids : multi_lrt(): Run tetraploid likelihood ratio tests segregation distortion parallel across many SNPs. lrt_men_g4(): Tetraploid likelihood ratio test segregation distortion using known genotypes. lrt_men_gl4(): Tetraploid likelihood ratio test segregation distortion using genotype likelihoods. offspring_gf_2(): Tetraploid offspring genotype frequencies two parameter model meiosis. offspring_gf_3(): Tetraploid offspring genotype frequencies three parameter model meiosis. simf1g(): Simulate genotypes F1 population tetraploids. simf1gl(): Simulate genotype likelihoods F1 population tetraploids. also provide functions “competing” methods: polymapr_test(): Test polymapR. chisq_g4(): Chi-squared test (accounting double reduction preferential pairing) genotypes known. chisq_gl4(): Chi-squared test (accounting double reduction preferential pairing) using genotype likelihoods. Details methods may found Gerard et al. (2025a) Gerard et al. (2025b).

title: Jointly tests for segregation distortion and number of incompatible genotypes — otest_g
code: # Run a test where genotypes 0, 1, and 2 are possible x <- c(10, 10, 4, 0, 5) otest_g(x = x, g1 = 1, g2 = 0) #> $statistic #> [1] 5.843033 #>  #> $p_value #> [1] 0.003160357 #>  #> $df #> [1] 2 #>  #> $alpha #> [1] 0.1666667 #>  #> $xi1 #> [1] NA #>  #> $xi2 #> [1] NA #>  #> $p_binom #> [1] 0.001580178 #>  #> $p_lrt #> [1] 0.05385196 #>   # polymapR's multiplication and the Bonferroni differ df <- expand.grid(p1 = seq(0, 1, length.out = 20), p2 = seq(0, 1, length.out = 20)) df$polymapr <- NA df$bonferroni <- NA for (i in seq_len(nrow(df))) {   df$polymapr[[i]] <- df$p1[[i]] * df$p2[[i]]   df$bonferroni[[i]] <- 2 * min(c(df$p1[[i]], df$p2[[i]], 0.5)) } graphics::plot(df$polymapr, df$bonferroni)

text: x data. Can one two forms: vector genotype counts. offspring genotypes known. matrix genotype log-likelihoods. genotype uncertainty. rows index individuals columns index possible genotypes. genotype log-likelihoods base e (natural log). p1_ploidy, p2_ploidy ploidy first second parent. even. p1, p2 One three forms: known genotype first second parent. vector genotype log-likelihoods first second parent. base e (natural log). NULL (completely unknown) model One six forms: "seg" Segmental allopolyploid. Allows arbitrary levels polysomic disomic inheritance. can account partial preferential pairing. also accounts double reduction simplex loci. "auto" Autopolyploid. Allows polysomic inheritance. double reduction. "auto_dr" Autopolyploid, allowing effects double reduction. "allo" Allopolyploid. complete disomic inheritance explored. "allo_pp" Allopolyploid, allowing effects partial preferential pairing. Though, autopolyploid (complete bivalent pairing double reduction) special case model. "auto_allo" complete disomic complete polysomic inheritance studied. outlier logical. allow outliers (TRUE) (FALSE)? ret_out logical. return probability individual outlier (TRUE) (FALSE)? ob default upper bound outlier proportion. db use complete equational segregation model ("ces") pure random chromatid segregation model ("prcs") determine upper bound(s) double reduction rate(s). See drbounds() details. ntry number times try optimization. probably want touch . opt local optimization, use bobyqa (Powell, 2009) L-BFGS-B (Byrd et al, 1995)? probably want touch . optg Initial global optimization used start local optimization. Methods described nloptr package (Johnson, 2008). probably want touch . Possible values : "NLOPT_GN_MLSL_LDS" MLSL (Multi-Level Single-Linkage). Kucherenko Sytsko (2005) "NLOPT_GN_ESCH" ESCH (evolutionary algorithm). da Silva Santos et al. (2010) "NLOPT_GN_CRS2_LM" Controlled Random Search (CRS) local mutation. Kaelo Ali (2006) "NLOPT_GN_ISRES" ISRES (Improved Stochastic Ranking Evolution Strategy). Runarsson Yao (2005) df_tol Threshold rank Jacobian degrees freedom calculation. accounts weak identifiability null model. probably want touch . chisq logical. using known genotypes, flags use chi-squared test Likelihood Ratio Test. title: Test for segregation distortion in a polyploid F1 population. — seg_lrt
code: set.seed(1) p1_ploidy <- 4 p1 <- 1 p2_ploidy <- 8 p2 <- 4 q <- gf_freq(   p1_g = p1,   p1_ploidy = p1_ploidy,   p1_gamma = 1,   p1_type = "mix",   p2_g = p2,   p2_ploidy = p2_ploidy,   p2_gamma= c(0.2, 0.2, 0.6),   p2_type = "mix",   pi = 0.01) nvec <- c(stats::rmultinom(n = 1, size = 200, prob = q)) gl <- simgl(nvec = nvec) seg_lrt(x = nvec, p1_ploidy = p1_ploidy, p2_ploidy = p2_ploidy, p1 = p1, p2 = p2)$p_value #> [1] 0.5084709 seg_lrt(x = gl, p1_ploidy = p1_ploidy, p2_ploidy = p2_ploidy, p1 = p1, p2 = p2)$p_value #> [1] 0.8546128

Log-likelihoods base e (natural log). p1_ploidy, p2_ploidy ploidy first second parent. even. p1 One three inputs vector parent 1's genotypes. matrix parent 1's genotype log-likelihoods. rows index loci columns index genotypes. Allows arbitrary levels polysomic disomic inheritance. can account partial preferential pairing. also accounts double reduction simplex loci. "auto" Autopolyploid. Allows polysomic inheritance. double reduction. "auto_dr" Autopolyploid, allowing effects double reduction. "allo" Allopolyploid. complete disomic inheritance explored. title: Parallelized likelihood ratio test for segregation distortion for arbitrary (even) ploidies. — seg_multi
code: # \donttest{ ## Assuming genotypes are known (typically a bad idea) glist <- multidog_to_g(   mout = ufit,   ploidy = 4,   type = "all_g",   p1 = "indigocrisp",   p2 = "sweetcrisp") p1_1 <- glist$p1 p2_1 <- glist$p2 g_1 <- glist$g s1 <- seg_multi(   g = g_1,   p1_ploidy = 4,   p2_ploidy = 4,   p1 = p1_1,   p2 = p2_1) s1[, c("snp", "p_value")] #>            snp     p_value #> 1   1_44673475 0.205984263 #> 2  11_28836119 0.196442803 #> 3  12_31029646 0.008922285 #> 4   12_8487773 0.995196014 #> 5    2_1426329 0.616648977 #> 6   2_20070837 0.160147847 #> 7   2_40108108 0.386228653 #> 8   4_37820371 0.157706919 #> 9   6_30619745 0.605526292 #> 10   6_4350249 0.674843558  ## Put NULL if you have absolutely no information on the parents s2 <- seg_multi(g = g_1, p1_ploidy = 4, p2_ploidy = 4, p1 = NULL, p2 = NULL) s2[, c("snp", "p_value")] #>            snp     p_value #> 1   1_44673475 0.205984263 #> 2  11_28836119 0.196442803 #> 3  12_31029646 0.008922285 #> 4   12_8487773 0.995196014 #> 5    2_1426329 0.616648977 #> 6   2_20070837 0.160147847 #> 7   2_40108108 0.386228653 #> 8   4_37820371 0.157706919 #> 9   6_30619745 0.605526292 #> 10   6_4350249 0.674843558  ## Using genotype likelihoods (typically a good idea) ## Also demonstrate parallelization through future package. glist <- multidog_to_g(   mout = ufit,   ploidy = 4,   type = "all_gl",   p1 = "indigocrisp",   p2 = "sweetcrisp") p1_2 <- glist$p1 p2_2 <- glist$p2 g_2 <- glist$g  # future::plan(future::multisession, workers = 2) # s3 <- seg_multi( #   g = g_2, #   p1_ploidy = 4, #   p2_ploidy = 4, #   p1 = p1_2, #   p2 = p2_2, #   ret_out = TRUE) # future::plan(future::sequential) # s3[, c("snp", "p_value")]  ## Outlier probabilities are returned if `ret_out = TRUE` # graphics::plot(s3$outprob[[6]], ylim = c(0, 1)) # }
